points_of_interest.name: Crossroads and Signpost
points_of_interest.description: At the crossroads of the Ditchway and Harrid's Path, an old signpost indicates: "N: Hag's Addle, S: House of the Harridwn (Inn), E: Dreg (Ferry), W: Lankshorn (Lankston)."

points_of_interest.name: The House of the Harridwn
points_of_interest.description: About three miles along the narrow, lesser-used Harrid's Path, travellers come upon a small, homely inn standing at the side of the trail. A meagre, forlorn barn adjoins it.
points_of_interest.tagline: A horde of welcoming children in maroon livery.
points_of_interest.interior: Cramped but cosy common room. In colder months, the small ironwork hearth holds a roaring fire. The guest rooms are situated along a winding hallway up a wonky, creaky stair. Curiously, there are dozens of guest rooms, occupying far more space than the inn's apparent size, when viewed from outside.
points_of_interest.exploring: The winding upper hallway ends at a stairway leading up to a blank ceiling. Knocking causes a hidden trapdoor to open, leading to the Hidden Bedroom.
points_of_interest.inhabitants: Mallowyn and Trellayde Occland serve as landladies. The inn is little frequented; it is likely that adventurers who enter are the only guests.
special_features: Bigger on the inside: The guest rooms occupy far more space than the inn's apparent size
Dead-end stair: Knocking on blank ceiling opens hidden trapdoor
Hidden bedroom: A gloomy attic space with woman's skeleton in bed with dried lavender and roses
Behind the barn: A glade of gravestones, several bear the name Occland, but graves for Tom, Mildred, and Greta Rumbelow are also present
Nightly Hauntings: Guest rooms haunted by ghosts of children
secrets: The inn was once the enchanted house of a powerful witch, Holstra Loom
When she died, her family interred her in the Hidden Bedroom
The Rumbelow children were slain by the witch's spirit
If the witch's skeleton is disturbed, her spirit rises as a spectre
Slaying the spirit puts an end to the inn's odd magic and the hauntings

points_of_interest.name: The Shrine to St Ponch
points_of_interest.description: In the north-west corner of the hex, 200 yards from the Ditchway, a valley overgrown with towering nodules of slimy black fungus conceals a shrine to St Ponch the prudent, patron saint of whalers and castaways.
points_of_interest.interior: A simple wooden porch (now rotten and slimy) above the statue. The whole structure is submerged in the mass of fungus.
points_of_interest.exploring: The fungus that dominates the valley is known as Hob's Lewd. 3d6 portions of its psychoactive slime may be gathered here.
special_features: Statue of St Ponch: A 2â€² high statue of white marble, depicting the saint as an old bearded man, bedraggled with sea foam and holding a whaling hook in one hand and a basket of scones in the other
Black fungus: The fungus is known as Hob's Lewd, 3d6 portions of psychoactive slime may be gathered
secrets: If the shrine is cleared, characters praying may receive the blessing of St Ponch: the ability to cast Create Food

npcs.name: Mallowyn Occland
npcs.title: Landlady
npcs.description: Nigh-identical elderly human sister with bright blue eyes and flowing, silver hair. Dressed in tidy knitwear.
npcs.speech: Shrill, wavering, punctuated with cackles. Woldish.
desires: Love to hear new songs and tales of daring
For the witch in the Hidden Bedroom to be left in peace
secrets: The landladies know of the inn's History
They are descendants of the witch
If asked about the ghostly children, the landladies claim they are here with another guest, Mr Rumbelow
They wish to draw attention away from the Hidden Bedroom

dm_notes: Services at the House of the Harridwn: Lodgings and food of common quality. Only one (tiny and quaintly appointed) private room is available; all other rooms are shared. Specialities: Buttered currant buns for 3cp each; local ale ("Hameth Foam") for 1sp a pint.
